captions.text:
>>GREETINGS WEARY TRAVELER.
>>THE GREAT OAK TREE.

I CAN'T BELIEVE IT!
I FOUND YOU!

>>YES, IT IS I, THE GREAT OAK TREE.
THE WISDOM OF TEN THOUSAND YEARS LIES WITHIN ME.
IT IS MY DUTY TO IMPART WISDOM TO THE--

OH!
WHAT ARE YOU DOING?

>>I WAS CHOPPING INTO YOU SO I CAN THE WISDOM
THAT'S ON THE INSIDE.

>>WHAT?
NO YOU FOOL.

IT'S NOT LITERALLY INSIDE-- OH STOP!
STOP YOU CRAZED LUMBERJACK.

LISTEN!
I WILL JUST TELL YOU THE WISDOM THAT I HAVE

OKAY THERE IS NO NEED-- AH!
>>JUST LOOKING FOR MY CAT.

IT'S KIND OF WINDY OUT.
>>OH, OH, MADAME.

PLEASE.
>>MISTY?

>>AH!
>>THAT PAPER WAS A RELATIVE.

>>SORRY ABOUT THAT GREAT OAK TREE.
>>IT'S OKAY.

MY WOUNDS SHALL HEAL.
OVER TIME-- OW!

>>HEY HAVE YOU FELLAS SEEN-- >>AH!
>>YOU CAN JUST KEEP THAT I GUESS.

>>AH!
>>TIME TO GET SOME SYRUP.

>>WHAT?
NO.

MADAME, DO NOT--
AH....

>>THIS ISN'T A MAPLE TREE IS IT?
>>NO.

>>JUST TRY TO...
YOU CAN JUST KEEP THAT.

>>WOW!
LOOK A TREE!

>>AH YOUTH.
I CANNOT STAY ANGRY WHEN CHILDREN ARE IN MY

MIDST.
COME LITTLE ONE, CLIMB--

OH! OW!
MOTHER EARTH!

>>I CAN'T CLIMB THIS STUPID TREE!
>>WHAT? NO. OW!

OW!
STOP HITTING ME WITH MY OWN BRANCHES YOU MONSTER.

>>OH LOOK ANOTHER TREE!
>>GO HOME AND READ THE LORAX!

>>OH.
THIS HAS BEEN THE WORST DAY OF MY--

AH!
DID YOU JUST STAB ME?

>>UH, MY GIRLFRIEND AND I WANTED TO CARVE
OUR NAMES INTO YOU.

>>I AM TEN THOUSAND YEARS OLD;
A LIVING EMBODIMENT OF

HISTORY AND WISDOM.
I AM NOT A FACEBOOK WALL.

>>SORRY MISTER TREE.
WE JUST WANTED THE WORLD TO KNOW HOW MUCH

WE LOVE EACH OTHER.
>>THEN SEND A GROUP TEXT.

>>MAYBE WE SHOULD JUST GO.
>>OW!

>>YOU CAN KEEP THAT.
>>YOU'RE SO NICE.

>>OH.
>>ALL RIGHT, IT LOOKS LIKE WE'LL PUT

THE PARKING LOT HERE.
>>WHAT?

NO, PLEASE.
>>YOU'RE GOING TO HAVE TO GO THROUGH ME

FIRST MAN.
>>FINALLY SOMEONE WHO-- OH, WHEN WAS THE LAST

TIME YOU BATHED?
OH, IT'S LIKE A DEAD MAN THREW UP AN OLD

BAND-AID IN A HOT CAR.
OH!

YOU WITH THE AX, FINISH THE JOB.
CUT ME DOWN.

comments.author: Rania Aslamy

comments.text:
+Ben Nett You don't have to reply to this if you don't want to. I just 
wanted to leave off with a few pointers. I did not go through the public 
school system, so I do not know if you will hear of them or not. If you 
ever hear of Java man, at one point he was a famous ape-man, there is not 
enough evidence to support him. If the two bones that constitute Java man 
had been discovered today, the facts around his discovery would have 
disqualified from science. The man who discovered him was actually off cite 
the whole time having someone else work the dig for him. He was not 
qualified for the job at the time and afterwards, on multiple occasions, 
changed the facts surrounding Java man's discovery. Another thing, if you 
ever see Ernst Haeckel's embryo drawings, don't believe them. Back in the 
1800's his embryo drawings were shown to be a fraud, but they were being 
used as evidence for evolution 20 years ago and they still might be, even 
though they are false. The last point I would like to make is to not 
believe in the Miller experiment. The atmosphere he used to create amino 
acids is not longer considered by evolutionary scientist to be the early 
atmosphere of the earth. If he had used the atmosphere that they no 
consider it to have been, his experiment would have created formaldehyde 
and cyanide. Both of those chemicals are highly toxic. I would also 
recommend you read Lee Strobel's book, The Case for a Creator. He grew up 
in a Christian family, but at a young age, turned to evolution and atheism 
(the literal definition of atheist is "without god" and is used to refer to 
people who do not believe there is a god). Years later he became a 
journalist and editor of the Chicago Tribune. Then his wife became a 
Christian and he decided to put God and evolution on trial and set up 
interviews some prominent scientist and prominent Bible scholars and in the 
end decided that the evidence was in favor of Christianity. To use a quote 
on the back of The Case for a Creator, "My road to atheism was paved by 
science . . . but, ironically, so was my later journey to God." He has 
written several books on his journey from evolution to Christianity. When 
he wrote The Case for a Creator, he was giving the same story as he had in 
previous books, only he updated the science in it to that of modern day. 
The copyright on it is 2004. I would recommend you read it, I have only 
read two or three chapters, and already I like it.

I will not proceed to drop the topic.
comments.author: Spaghetti the TenTac

comments.text:
+Sir Rutherford Master of All Things Trigonometric Not responding would

comment. That is, unless someone says something really stupid. So just drop 
the topic, unless you really want to continue talking, in which case my 
email is:


superkillermonke@gmail.com

on that is pointless.


This is likely going to be my final post on this.


GOOD DAY SIR!
(Btw: You were arguing with a 11 year old the whole time. I'm not sure if 
you realized that.
comments.author: Ben “SuperKillerMonkE” Nett

comments.text:
+Ben Nett I do not remember where I saw the option, but you can opt to not 
receive those email notifications from specific threads. If a particular 
comment thread is filling you inbox, you can just opt to not receive those 
notifications. I am tempted to do that to another comment thread. I made 
the mistake of commenting on something that already had over 200 replies. 
Within the next couple of hours, I received a dozen emails from that 
thread, and all the comments they contained I had no interest in. I also 
believe that God is real and is not an impossibility, however, it is a 
personal choice for whether or not you see the proof. If you do not want to 
believe in Him, there is nothing I can do about that and it is pointless to 
argue about it. AS such, this may be my last comment to this thread.
comments.author: Spaghetti the TenTac

comments.author: Ben “SuperKillerMonkE” Nett

comments.text:
This argument is pointless. Really, seriously, it is. That's because no 
sides have proof. Even though the science side has a lot of material, it 
does not have an explanation for how the universe came into existence. And 
even though the religious side has faith, there is no actual evidence of 
God. In addition to this, it is clear that nobody will give any ground 
whatsoever pertaining to their own belief systems. Finally, we humans have 
a flaw that makes it considerably more difficult, albeit possible, to 
convince us without visual evidence. Put that all together and what does 
one have? An argument impossible to win and incredibly annoying to all 
participants. So, I beseech you all, please don't continue this. It will 
only make things worse.
comments.author: Charlie Anderson

comments.text:
+ Ben

I agree with spaghetti, but let me add to this.

You're just speculating. There is no evidence the bible is false; you just 
choose to think so. 

How does Hod break the laws of physics? Proof of a creator is everywhere. 
The fact that matter and energy exist proves God. The reason God doesn't 
fly down and say "here I am" is because he doesn't have to. He already did. 
Through science we see him, but also through the bible. Even if more proof 
came, I bet you would still find a way to dismiss it. It's not a lack of 
evidence, but a lack of responding to it.

On religion, there is a difference between religion and true biblical 
Christianity. The latter is a relationship, not an order. Look at the bible 
compared to other religions it is the only one to:

A. Not require good works for salvation.

B. Not have errors and contradictions.

C. Offer a true and loving relationship and not just pleasing an overlord.
comments.author: Sir Rutherford Master of All Things Trigonometric

comments.text:
+Sir Rutherford Master of All Things Trigonometric 
I suppose you can't prove anything, and I can't know everything, so there 
could be some proof. I couldn't think of what that proof may be (please 
name some). There's proof against him though. I also don't know it was 
written by ONE delusional mind, it could of been many minds.


I can say this though. The idea of an all powerful being that created the 
universe and breaks his own laws of physics, as well as never physically 
reveal himself for some reason that apparently 'no one can comprehend' 
(which is the lamest excuse I have ever heard), and as I said before was 
likely created by people trying to explain the universe but instead do it 
irrationally with their inferior knowledge of the world is silly. Think of 
any religion you know of. Does it seem silly? It might, and that's what 
others think of think of your religion. So why should yours be right? They 
probably have plenty of 'proof' too.


I guess the morale of the story is to be open minded. If someone can 
present convincing evidence that their religion exists, then I would 
consider it. Of course I'll have to do over my mental barrier, which I 
would not look forward to.
comments.author: Ben “SuperKillerMonkE” Nett

comments.text:
+Spaghetti the TenTac 
Here's your first error: The big bang didn't happen at a central point. It 
happened everywhere. I can't argue the accuracy of the dating, but it's the 
best we have. If you didn't notice it said to give or take 0.05 billion 
years. This is a pretty good guess. Now, the accuracy of your dating is not 
very accurate. Your basis is a metaphysical being that we have no proof of 
existing and the idea of it likely came from a human mind trying to explain 
what he doesn't know, and now is causing conflict with things we do know. 
You only could know of this belief in two ways:


1. The not very accurate method of passing things down via speech,


2. or a mistranslated many times over book (since it was first translated 
way before we had good translations) that was also likely from a delusional 
mind.


Mmmm, yeah, some serious credibility there. I was raised in a christian 
household, I'm not even in my teens but I have enough sense to find this 
silly. I doubt I can convince you otherwise, but you at least have to 
accept that God's explanations aren't very accurate. We can also disprove 
that the Earth isn't 6,000 to 10,000 years old because it would take way 
longer for evolution to take place, unless you're anti-evolution too, in 
which it wouldn't surprise me.
comments.author: Ben “SuperKillerMonkE” Nett

comments.text:
+Ben Nett Let me point out that both of the dating methods you mentioned 
may or may not be true. The first dating method you mentioned is based off 
of the assumption that the big bang took place. Basically, if everything 
started at a central point and you know the rate of expansion, 
acceleration, and current distance, then you can calculate the age. If the 
big bang did not take place and God created the universe, then it would no 
longer be a valid way of dating.
The second method you mentioned, relies on two isotopes. If you know the 
rate of decay of an isotope, then you can date something based off of the 
ratio between it and the isotope it decays into. However it can be thrown 
off. If the conditions are right, isotopes can leech into the object being 
dated from the environment. The reverse can also happen where isotopes can 
leech out of the object being dated into the surrounding environment. 
Depending on which happens, it will make the object come out younger or 
older than it actually is. There is also no way of knowing if leeching 
occurred other than using other dating methods and comparing dates. But 
what if leeching also occurred with them? There would be no way of knowing 
which one had the correct date, or if they all are wrong. There is also 
another source of possible error. If God created the universe as recorded 
in Genesis, then He could have created the object with a preexisting ratio 
between the two isotopes. If that happened, it could throw off the date 
significantly.
Those billion year dates are based on assumptions and beliefs and may or 
may not be true. The date I mentioned of the earth and universe being 6,000 
to 10,000 years old is based off of my religion which is also a belief. The 
reason I believe that my younger date is the true one is because I believe 
the God of the Bible exists and I look around me and see proof of that (I 
even know someone that was miraculously healed).
comments.author: Spaghetti the TenTac

comments.text:
+Spaghetti the TenTac I know you didn't want to debate this but:


1. We weren't even talking about the universe, but it's generally accepted 
it's about 13-14 billion years old. We know this because we can calculate 
it's age based on the universe's current acceleration of its expansion.


2. We have a pretty accurate estimate of the Earths age: 'The age of the 
Earth is 4.54 ± 0.05 billion years (4.54 × 109 years ± 1%). This age is 
based on evidence from radiometric age dating of meteorite material and is 
consistent with the radiometric ages of the oldest-known terrestrial and 
lunar samples.'


Good day.
comments.author: Ben “SuperKillerMonkE” Nett

comments.text:
+Ben Nett The universe is about 6,000 to 10,000 years old. I am not going 
to debate that fact here though. With 166 replies (167 when I post this), I 
think that this comment thread is long enough without me adding to it 
discussing things. I will say this though, no one really knows how old the 
universe is. There are a variety of different beliefs and theories about 
how old it is, but the simple fact remains that none of us were around back 
then and therefore cannot be absolutely sure of how old it is.
comments.author: Spaghetti the TenTac

comments.text: +S Baer It's actually 4.54 billion years old, not million.

come out of them with a deeper and more meaningful relationship with God.
